page.title: 04STRIP LYNCHETS
page.content: The Mere lynchets are still there, a bit reduced, less productive, but still there. These saxon strip fields are narrow ledges cut into the side of the hills either side of the hand-shaped combes running north into Mere Down a mile east of Mere. There are between five and six grassy levelled strips along the lower slope of each combe and are best seen in the low winter sun. Varying in width from four to nine metres, the different levels are still joined by ramps. The high saxon fields at the head of the main valley have now really gone, though the outlines are just discernable. Where they were ploughed and rotated they are now occasionally grazed by sheep. There are fewer downland wild flowers but several species of orchid survive.
